ground_truth: The street lights are reflected in the puddles on the damp pavements. At last, he slows down and looks around him. Ahead is a small patch of worn grass in a children's playground. He's alone. He sits wearily on the edge of the pavement, hunching his shoulders against the cold and damp. He looks up as the streetlight above his head flickers and goes out. In the playground, the empty swings begin to move. The roundabout turns and a seesaw clumps down onto the grass. In front of him, a huge black dog looms out of the bushes. Harry slowly rises to his feet. Harry pulls out his wand and stumbles backwards onto the pavement. A bright light approaches. A purple triple-decker bus draws up. The conductor reads from a dirty piece of card. Putting the card in his pocket, he looks down at Harry. Harry stares nervously at the bushes. Stan picks up the trunk, and Harry steps inside the bus. On the lower deck is a row of beds, one of which is occupied. Above his head, Harry sees galleries and a chandelier hanging from the roof. Stan Shunpike turns the handle of his machine and gives Harry a bus ticket. Stan knocks on the driver's window. The Rastafarian shrunken head, hanging above the driver, laughs. Ernie starts the bus. Harry falls backwards onto a bed. Ernie peers through thick glasses and drives erratically. The bus screeches to a halt. Harry's face hits the window. An old lady with a walking frame shuffles in front of the bus. Harry sees a picture in Stan's newspaper. Two London buses drive straight at them. Ernie pulls a lever. The bus and its occupants become narrow enough to squeeze between them. The bus hurdles off again down a narrow street. Harry hits the window again. They bump a parked car. Tom, the hunchback innkeeper, grins at Harry. The purple bus disappears into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron. Inside the gloomy public house, a man sits reading a book while a spoon stirs itself around a cup. Chairs turn themselves upside down onto the tables. In a room upstairs, Harry finds his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. As Tom hauls him up, Harry calls his owl. Harry gazes down at the busy marketplace below his window. A high-level train rattles past. Harry goes to the pile of books on the low table by the fire. One of the books is growling. He looks at its hairy cover, staring, glassy eyes and sharp, pointed teeth. Suddenly, the book goes berserk, snapping its covers. It leaps out of his hands and starts to snap at his feet.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The road lamps are mirrored in the pools on the moist sidewalks. Finally, he reduces speed and glances around him. Forward is a little area of tired turf in a children's park. He's solitary. He settles wearily on the rim of the sidewalk, hunching his shoulders against the chilly and moist. He glances up as the streetlamp above his head blinks and goes out. In the park, the vacant swings commence to sway. The carousel rotates and a seesaw clumps down onto the turf. Before him, a giant black canine looms out of the shrubs. Harry slowly rises to his feet. Harry pulls out his wand and stumbles backward onto the sidewalk. A vivid light nears. A purple triple-decker coach draws up. The conductor reads from a filthy piece of card. Putting the card in his pocket, he glances down at Harry. Harry stares nervously at the shrubs. Stan lifts the trunk, and Harry steps inside the coach. On the lower level is a row of bunks, one of which is occupied. Above his head, Harry sees galleries and a chandelier dangling from the ceiling. Stan Shunpike rotates the handle of his apparatus and gives Harry a coach ticket. Stan taps on the driver's glass. The Rastafarian shrunken head, hanging above the driver, laughs. Ernie begins the coach. Harry falls backward onto a bunk. Ernie peers through thick spectacles and drives erratically. The coach screeches to a stop. Harry's face hits the glass. An elderly lady with a walking frame shuffles before the coach. Harry sees a photo in Stan's newspaper. Two London coaches drive straight at them. Ernie pulls a lever. The coach and its occupants become narrow enough to compress between them. The coach hurdles off again down a slender road. Harry hits the glass again. They bump a parked vehicle. Tom, the hunchback innkeeper, grins at Harry. The purple coach vanishes into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron. Inside the dim public house, a man sits perusing a book while a spoon stirs itself around a cup. Chairs turn themselves upside down onto the tables. In a chamber upstairs, Harry finds his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. As Tom hauls him up, Harry calls his owl. Harry gazes down at the bustling marketplace below his glass. A high-level train rattles past. Harry goes to the stack of books on the low table by the fire. One of the books is growling. He glances at its hairy cover, staring, glassy eyes and sharp, pointed teeth. Suddenly, the book goes berserk, snapping its covers. It leaps out of his hands and starts to snap at his feet.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The street lights are reflected in the puddles on the damp pavements. At last, he slows down and looks around him. Ahead is a small patch of worn grass in a children's playground. He's alone. The edge of the pavement is sat on by him wearily, and his shoulders are hunched against the cold and damp. Up is looked by him as the streetlight above his head is flickered and turned out. In the playground, the empty swings begin to move. The roundabout is turned and a seesaw is clumped down onto the grass. In front of him, out of the bushes looms a huge black dog. His feet are slowly risen to by Harry. Harry's wand is pulled out and he stumbles backwards onto the pavement. A bright light is approached. Up is drawn by a purple triple-decker bus. The conductor reads from a dirty piece of card. The card is put in his pocket, and Harry is looked down upon by him. At the bushes, Harry stares nervously. The trunk is picked up by Stan, and inside the bus, Harry steps. On the lower deck is a row of beds, one of which occupies someone. Above his head, galleries and a chandelier hanging from the roof are seen by Harry. The handle of his machine is turned by Stan Shunpike and a bus ticket is given to Harry. On the driver's window, Stan knocks. The Rastafarian shrunken head, hanging above the driver, laughs. The bus is started by Ernie. Harry falls backwards onto a bed. Through thick glasses, Ernie peers and drives erratically. A halt is screeched to by the bus. Harry's face is hit against the window. In front of the bus shuffles an old lady with a walking frame. In Stan's newspaper, a picture is seen by Harry. At them, two London buses drive straight. A lever is pulled by Ernie. The bus and its occupants are narrowed enough to be squeezed between them. Down a narrow street, the bus hurdles off again. Against the window, Harry is hit again. A parked car is bumped. At Harry, Tom, the hunchback innkeeper, grins. Into the night, the purple bus disappears. Tom is followed by Harry into the Leaky Cauldron. Inside the gloomy public house, a book is read by a man while a spoon is stirred around a cup by itself. Upside down onto the tables, chairs are turned by themselves. In a room upstairs, his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge, are found by Harry. As Tom hauls him up, his owl is called by Harry. Down at the busy marketplace below his window, Harry gazes. Past rattles a high-level train. The pile of books on the low table by the fire is gone to by Harry. One of the books is growling. Its hairy cover, staring, glassy eyes, and sharp, pointed teeth are looked at by him. Suddenly, berserk goes the book, snapping its covers. Out of his hands, it leaps and starts to snap at his feet.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Street lights reflect in puddles on damp pavements. He slows down, looking around. Ahead is a worn grass patch in a playground. Alone, he sits on the pavement's edge, hunching against the cold. The streetlight flickers and goes out. Swings move, the roundabout turns, and a seesaw clumps down. A huge black dog emerges from the bushes. Harry rises, pulls out his wand, and stumbles back. A bright light approaches—a purple triple-decker bus. The conductor reads from a card, then looks at Harry. Stan picks up the trunk, and Harry boards the bus. On the lower deck are beds, one occupied. Above, Harry sees galleries and a chandelier. Stan gives Harry a ticket and knocks on the driver's window. The shrunken head above the driver laughs. Ernie starts the bus, driving erratically. The bus halts, and Harry hits the window. An old lady shuffles in front. Harry sees a picture in Stan's newspaper. Two London buses approach. Ernie pulls a lever, and the bus narrows to squeeze through. It speeds down a narrow street, bumping a parked car. Tom, the innkeeper, grins at Harry. The bus vanishes into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron. Inside, a man reads while a spoon stirs a cup. Chairs turn upside down onto tables. Upstairs, Harry finds his owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. Tom helps him up, and Harry calls his owl. He gazes at the marketplace below. A train rattles past. Harry approaches a pile of books by the fire. One book growls, with a hairy cover, staring eyes, and sharp teeth. Suddenly, it goes berserk, snapping at his feet.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Street lights reflect in puddles on damp pavements. He slows down, looking around. Ahead is a worn grass patch in a playground. Alone, he sits on the pavement edge, hunching against the cold. The streetlight flickers out. Swings move, the roundabout turns, and a seesaw clumps down. A huge black dog appears. Harry rises, pulls out his wand, and stumbles back. A bright light approaches—a purple triple-decker bus. The conductor reads a card, pockets it, and looks at Harry, who nervously stares at the bushes. Stan picks up the trunk, and Harry boards. On the lower deck, beds are arranged, one occupied. Above, Harry sees galleries and a chandelier. Stan gives Harry a ticket and knocks on the driver's window. The shrunken head laughs. Ernie starts the bus, driving erratically. The bus halts, and Harry hits the window. An old lady shuffles in front. Harry sees a picture in Stan's newspaper. Two buses approach. Ernie pulls a lever, squeezing between them. The bus speeds down a narrow street, bumping a car. Tom, the innkeeper, grins at Harry. The bus vanishes into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron. Inside, a man reads while a spoon stirs a cup. Chairs turn upside down onto tables. Upstairs, Harry finds his owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. Tom helps him up, and Harry calls his owl. He gazes at the marketplace below. A train rattles past. Harry approaches a pile of books by the fire. One book growls, with a hairy cover, staring eyes, and sharp teeth. It goes berserk, snapping and leaping at his feet.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The street lights cast their reflections in the numerous puddles scattered across the damp pavements, creating a shimmering effect. Finally, he slows his pace and takes a moment to look around at his surroundings. Just ahead of him lies a small, worn patch of grass situated within a children's playground. He finds himself completely alone in this quiet setting. With a weary sigh, he sits down on the edge of the pavement, hunching his shoulders to brace against the biting cold and persistent dampness. As he glances upward, the streetlight directly above his head flickers momentarily before going out completely. In the playground, the empty swings begin to sway gently, the roundabout starts to turn slowly, and a seesaw clumps down onto the grass with a soft thud. Suddenly, in front of him, a huge, imposing black dog emerges from the shadows of the bushes. Harry slowly rises to his feet, feeling a sense of unease. He pulls out his wand and stumbles backward onto the pavement, trying to maintain his balance. A bright light approaches in the distance, growing larger and more distinct. A purple triple-decker bus comes to a stop right in front of him. The conductor, holding a dirty piece of card, reads from it before tucking it back into his pocket. He then looks down at Harry, who is nervously staring at the bushes. Stan, the conductor, picks up Harry's trunk, and Harry steps inside the bus. On the lower deck, there is a row of beds, one of which is already occupied by someone. Above his head, Harry notices galleries and a chandelier hanging elegantly from the roof. Stan Shunpike turns the handle of his machine and hands Harry a bus ticket. Stan then knocks on the driver's window. The Rastafarian shrunken head, which is hanging above the driver, lets out a laugh. Ernie, the driver, starts the bus, causing Harry to fall backward onto a bed. Ernie peers through his thick glasses and drives in an erratic manner. The bus screeches to a sudden halt, and Harry's face hits the window with a thud. An old lady with a walking frame shuffles slowly in front of the bus. Harry catches sight of a picture in Stan's newspaper. Two London buses are driving straight toward them. Ernie quickly pulls a lever, and the bus, along with its occupants, becomes narrow enough to squeeze between the oncoming buses. The bus then hurdles off again down a narrow street, and Harry hits the window once more. They bump into a parked car along the way. Tom, the hunchback innkeeper, grins at Harry as the purple bus disappears into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron. Inside the gloomy public house, a man sits quietly reading a book while a spoon stirs itself around a cup. Chairs turn themselves upside down onto the tables, as if by magic. In a room upstairs, Harry finds his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. As Tom helps him up, Harry calls to his owl. He gazes down at the bustling marketplace below his window, where a high-level train rattles past. Harry then goes to the pile of books on the low table by the fire. One of the books is growling ominously. He looks at its hairy cover, noticing its staring, glassy eyes and sharp, pointed teeth. Suddenly, the book goes berserk, snapping its covers wildly. It leaps out of his hands and starts to snap aggressively at his feet.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: The street lights, casting their bright, artificial glow, mirror their reflections in the numerous puddles that are scattered haphazardly across the damp pavements lining the street. This creates a shimmering, almost ethereal effect on the ground. Eventually, he slows his brisk pace, pausing for a moment to take a look around at his quiet and deserted surroundings. Just ahead of him lies a small, worn patch of grass, nestled comfortably within a children's playground. He finds himself completely alone in this serene yet slightly eerie setting. With a long, weary sigh, he sits down on the very edge of the pavement, hunching his shoulders as he braces himself against the biting cold and the persistent dampness in the air. As he casts a glance upward, the streetlight directly above his head flickers uncertainly for a brief moment before it goes out completely, plunging the area into relative darkness. In the playground, the empty swings begin to sway gently back and forth, the roundabout slowly starts to rotate, and a seesaw clumps down onto the grass with a soft thud. Suddenly, emerging from the shadows of the nearby bushes, a huge, imposing black dog becomes visible, catching his attention. Harry slowly rises to his feet, feeling a growing sense of unease as he does so. He pulls out his wand, stumbling backward onto the pavement as he tries to maintain his balance. In the distance, a bright light approaches steadily, growing larger and more distinct with every passing second. A purple triple-decker bus comes to a stop right in front of him. The conductor, holding a grimy piece of card, reads aloud from it before tucking it back away into his pocket. He then looks down at Harry, who is nervously staring at the ominous bushes. Stan, the conductor, lifts Harry's heavy trunk, and Harry steps inside the bus. On the lower deck, there is a row of beds, each neatly arranged, one of which is already occupied by someone quietly resting. Above his head, Harry's eyes are drawn to the galleries and a chandelier that hangs elegantly from the roof of the bus. Stan Shunpike, with a practiced motion, turns the handle of his ticket machine and hands Harry a bus ticket. Stan then knocks firmly on the driver's window. A Rastafarian shrunken head, hanging above the driver, lets out a laugh. Ernie, the driver, starts the bus, and the sudden movement causes Harry to fall backward onto a bed. Ernie peers through his thick, round glasses and drives in an unpredictable, erratic manner. The bus screeches to a sudden halt, and Harry's face hits the window with a thud. An old lady, moving slowly and carefully with a walking frame, shuffles across the space in front of the bus. Harry catches sight of a picture in Stan's newspaper, showing two London buses hurtling directly toward them. With quick reflexes, Ernie pulls a lever, and the bus, along with its slightly bewildered occupants, becomes narrow enough to squeeze neatly between the oncoming buses. The bus then goes barreling off again down a narrow street, causing Harry to hit the window once more. They bump into a parked car as they make their way. Tom, the hunchbacked innkeeper, grins warmly at Harry as the purple bus disappears into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron. Inside the dimly lit, gloomy public house, a man sits quietly immersed in reading a book as a spoon stirs itself lazily around in a cup. Chairs, as if animated by magic, turn themselves upside down onto the tables. In a room located upstairs, Harry finds his snowy owl alongside the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. As Tom helps him up, Harry calls out to his owl. He then gazes down at the bustling marketplace below his window, where a high-level train rattles past noisily. Harry turns his attention to the pile of books resting on the low table by the fire. One of the books, noticeably peculiar, is growling ominously. He examines its hairy cover, noticing its staring, glassy eyes and sharp, pointed teeth. Suddenly, the book goes berserk, snapping its covers wildly in a frenzy. It leaps out of his hands and starts to snap aggressively at his feet.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The street lights cast their glow onto the wet surfaces, creating shimmering reflections in the puddles scattered across the damp pavements. Eventually, he decelerates his pace and takes a moment to survey his surroundings. In the distance, he notices a small, worn patch of grass that forms part of a children's playground. Realizing he is alone, he lowers himself wearily onto the edge of the pavement, drawing his shoulders inward to shield himself from the biting cold and dampness. As he sits there, he glances upward just in time to see the streetlight above him flicker before it extinguishes completely. In the playground, the empty swings begin to sway gently, the roundabout starts to rotate slowly, and the seesaw makes a dull thud as it drops onto the grass. Suddenly, a large black dog emerges ominously from the bushes in front of him. With a sense of urgency, Harry slowly rises to his feet, reaching for his wand as he stumbles backward onto the pavement. A bright light catches his attention, and he watches as a purple triple-decker bus comes to a stop nearby. The conductor steps forward, reading aloud from a dirty piece of card before tucking it back into his pocket and casting a glance down at Harry. Harry, feeling a mix of apprehension and curiosity, keeps his eyes fixed nervously on the bushes. Stan, the conductor, picks up Harry's trunk, prompting Harry to step inside the bus. On the lower deck, he observes a row of beds, one of which is already occupied. As he looks up, he notices galleries and a chandelier hanging from the roof above him. Stan Shunpike turns the handle of a machine and hands Harry a bus ticket. Stan then knocks on the driver's window, where a Rastafarian shrunken head dangles and laughs. Ernie, the driver, starts the bus, causing Harry to lose his balance and fall backward onto a bed. Ernie, peering through thick glasses, drives with a reckless abandon, and the bus screeches to a halt, causing Harry's face to slam against the window. Outside, an old lady with a walking frame shuffles slowly in front of the bus. Harry's attention is drawn to a picture in Stan's newspaper, but before he can process it, two London buses appear to be driving straight at them. Ernie quickly pulls a lever, and the bus, along with its occupants, compresses to fit narrowly between the oncoming vehicles. The bus then accelerates down a narrow street, and Harry is thrown against the window once more. They collide with a parked car, and Tom, the hunchback innkeeper, grins at Harry as the purple bus vanishes into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron, where the dimly lit public house reveals a man engrossed in a book while a spoon stirs itself in a cup nearby. Chairs autonomously flip themselves upside down onto the tables. Upstairs, in a room, Harry discovers his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. As Tom helps him up, Harry calls out to his owl. He then gazes down at the bustling marketplace below his window, where a high-level train rattles past. Moving to the pile of books on the low table by the fire, he picks up one that is growling. He examines its hairy cover, noting the staring, glassy eyes and sharp, pointed teeth. Without warning, the book goes berserk, snapping its covers open and leaping from his hands, then begins snapping at his feet.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The street lights reflect in the puddles on the damp pavements as he slows down and surveys his surroundings. Spotting a small patch of worn grass in a deserted children's playground, he sits wearily on the pavement's edge, hunching against the cold. The streetlight above flickers and goes out, and the playground equipment eerily moves on its own. A huge black dog emerges from the bushes, prompting Harry to rise and draw his wand, stumbling backward. A bright light approaches, revealing a purple triple-decker bus. The conductor reads from a card, pockets it, and looks at Harry, who nervously glances at the bushes. Stan picks up Harry's trunk, and Harry boards the bus, noticing the row of beds and a chandelier above. Stan gives Harry a ticket and knocks on the driver's window, where a laughing shrunken head hangs. Ernie starts the bus, driving erratically, causing Harry to fall onto a bed. The bus screeches to a halt as an old lady shuffles by, and Harry sees a picture in Stan's newspaper. Two London buses approach, but Ernie pulls a lever, allowing them to squeeze through. The bus speeds down a narrow street, bumping a parked car, and Tom, the innkeeper, grins at Harry as the bus disappears into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron, where a man reads a book and chairs turn themselves onto tables. Upstairs, Harry finds his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. As Tom helps him up, Harry calls his owl and gazes at the bustling marketplace below. A train rattles past as Harry examines a pile of books by the fire. One book, with a hairy cover and sharp teeth, suddenly goes berserk, leaping from his hands and snapping at his feet.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The street lights, casting a warm yet eerie glow typical of British urban areas, are reflected in the puddles on the damp pavements of a place empty of its usual bustle. At last, he slows down and looks around him, searching for any sign of movement. Ahead is a small patch of worn grass in a children's playground, a common feature in many London neighborhoods. He's alone. He sits wearily on the edge of the pavement, hunching his shoulders against the cold and damp of an English night. He looks up as the streetlight above his head flickers and goes out, plunging the playground into deeper darkness. In the playground, the empty swings, reminiscent of children’s laughter now absent, begin to move. The roundabout, long since rusted by the rain, turns and a seesaw clumps down onto the grass. In front of him, a huge black dog, its eyes glowing in the dim light, looms out of the bushes. Harry slowly rises to his feet. Harry pulls out his wand, a twelve-inch holly rod with a phoenix feather core, and stumbles backwards onto the pavement. A bright light approaches through the shadows. A purple triple-decker bus, known as the Knight Bus and a magical vehicle for stranded wizards, draws up. The conductor, Stan Shunpike, reads from a dirty piece of card that lists Harry’s name. Putting the card in his pocket, he looks down at Harry. Harry stares nervously at the bushes, expecting trouble. Stan picks up the trunk, and Harry steps inside the bus. On the lower deck is a row of beds, one of which is occupied by a snoring wizard. Above his head, Harry sees galleries and a chandelier hanging from the roof, swaying with the bus’s motion. Stan Shunpike turns the handle of his machine, a ticket dispenser, and gives Harry a bus ticket. Stan knocks on the driver’s window. The Rastafarian shrunken head, hanging above the driver, laughs with a raspy cackle. Ernie Prang, the driver, starts the bus. Harry falls backwards onto a bed, jostled by the sudden movement. Ernie peers through thick glasses and drives erratically, weaving through the city streets. The bus screeches to a halt. Harry's face hits the window, jarred by the abrupt stop. An old lady with a walking frame shuffles in front of the bus, undeterred by its bizarre appearance. Harry sees a picture in Stan’s newspaper, depicting the magical world’s latest headlines. Two London buses, oblivious to the Knight Bus's magical nature, drive straight at them. Ernie pulls a lever. The bus and its occupants become narrow enough to squeeze between them, a trick made possible by enchantment. The bus hurdles off again down a narrow street. Harry hits the window again as they take a sharp corner. They bump a parked car, whose alarm goes off. Tom, the hunchback innkeeper famous for his connections with magical folk, grins at Harry. The purple bus disappears into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron, a secret entrance to the magical world. Inside the gloomy public house, a man sits reading a book on advanced charms while a spoon stirs itself around a cup of steaming tea. Chairs turn themselves upside down onto the tables, tidying up the room. In a room upstairs, Harry finds his snowy owl, Hedwig, and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Cornelius Fudge, who often wears a bowler hat. As Tom hauls him up, Harry calls his owl, feeling a sense of relief at seeing her. Harry gazes down at the busy marketplace, Diagon Alley, buzzing with witches and wizards, below his window. A high-level train, the Hogwarts Express on a test run, rattles past in the distance. Harry goes to the pile of books on the low table by the fire. One of the books is growling, a notorious copy of The Monster Book of Monsters. He looks at its hairy cover, staring, glassy eyes and sharp, pointed teeth. Suddenly, the book goes berserk, snapping its covers. It leaps out of his hands and starts to snap at his feet, demonstrating the challenges of managing magical creatures.

test_cases.name: Addition (~50%)
test_cases.description: The street lights are reflected in the puddles on the damp pavements. At last he slows down and looks around him. Ahead is a small patch of worn grass in a children's playground. He is alone. He sits wearily on the edge of the pavement hunching his shoulders against the cold and damp. He looks up as the streetlight above his head flickers and goes out. In the playground the empty swings begin to move. The roundabout turns and a seesaw clumps down onto the grass. In front of him a huge black dog looms out of the bushes. Harry slowly rises to his feet. Harry pulls out his wand and stumbles backwards onto the pavement. A bright light approaches. A purple tripledecker bus draws up. The conductor reads from a dirty piece of card. Putting the card in his pocket he looks down at Harry. Harry stares nervously at the bushes. Stan picks up the trunk and Harry steps inside the bus. On the lower deck is a row of beds one of which is occupied. Above his head Harry sees galleries and a chandelier hanging from the roof. Stan Shunpike turns the handle of his machine and gives Harry a bus ticket. Stan knocks on the driver's window. The Rastafarian shrunken head hanging above the driver laughs. Ernie starts the bus. Harry falls backwards onto a bed. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. Ernie peers through thick glasses and drives erratically. The bus screeches to a halt. Harry's face hits the window. An old lady with a walking frame shuffles in front of the bus. Harry sees a picture in Stan's newspaper. Two London buses drive straight at them. Ernie pulls a lever. The bus and its occupants become narrow enough to squeeze between them. The bus hurdles off again down a narrow street. Harry hits the window again. They bump a parked car. Tom the hunchback innkeeper grins at Harry. The purple bus disappears into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron. Inside the gloomy public house a man sits reading a book while a spoon stirs itself around a cup. Chairs turn themselves upside down onto the tables. In a room upstairs Harry finds his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic Mr Fudge. As Tom hauls him up Harry calls his owl. Harry gazes down at the busy marketplace below his window. A highlevel train rattles past. Harry goes to the pile of books on the low table by the fire. One of the books is growling. He looks at its hairy cover staring glassy eyes and sharp pointed teeth. Suddenly the book goes berserk snapping its covers. It leaps out of his hands and starts to snap at his feet.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: The street lights are reflected in the puddles on the damp pavements. At last he slows down and looks around him. Ahead is a small patch of worn grass in a children's playground. He is alone. He sits wearily on the edge of the pavement hunching his shoulders against the cold and damp. He looks up as the streetlight above his head flickers and goes out. In the playground the empty swings begin to move. The roundabout turns and a seesaw clumps down onto the grass. In front of him a huge black dog looms out of the bushes. Harry slowly rises to his feet. Harry pulls out his wand and stumbles backwards onto the pavement. A bright light approaches. A purple tripledecker bus draws up. The conductor reads from a dirty piece of card. Putting the card in his pocket he looks down at Harry. Harry stares nervously at the bushes. Stan picks up the trunk and Harry steps inside the bus. On the lower deck is a row of beds one of which is occupied. Above his head Harry sees galleries and a chandelier hanging from the roof. Stan Shunpike turns the handle of his machine and gives Harry a bus ticket. Stan knocks on the driver's window. The Rastafarian shrunken head hanging above the driver laughs. Ernie starts the bus. Harry falls backwards onto a bed. test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The street lights are reflected in the puddles on the damp pavements. At last, the cat slows down and looks around him. Ahead is a small patch of worn grass in a children's playground. The cat's alone. The cat sits wearily on the edge of the pavement, hunching its shoulders against the cold and damp. The cat looks up as the streetlight above its head flickers and goes out. In the playground, the empty swings begin to move. The roundabout turns and a seesaw clumps down onto the grass. In front of the cat, a huge black dog looms out of the bushes. The giraffe slowly rises to its feet. The giraffe pulls out its wand and stumbles backwards onto the pavement. A bright light approaches. A purple triple-decker bus draws up. The waiter reads from a dirty piece of card. Putting the card in its pocket, the waiter looks down at the giraffe. The giraffe stares nervously at the bushes. The elephant picks up the trunk, and the giraffe steps inside the bus. On the lower deck is a row of beds, one of which is occupied. Above its head, the giraffe sees galleries and a chandelier hanging from the roof. The flamingo turns the handle of its machine and gives the giraffe a bus ticket. The flamingo knocks on the driver's window. The Rastafarian shrunken head, hanging above the driver, laughs. The penguin starts the bus. The giraffe falls backwards onto a bed. The penguin peers through thick glasses and drives erratically. The bus screeches to a halt. The giraffe's face hits the window. An old lady with a walking frame shuffles in front of the bus. The giraffe sees a picture in the flamingo's newspaper. Two London buses drive straight at them. The penguin pulls a lever. The bus and its occupants become narrow enough to squeeze between them. The bus hurdles off again down a narrow street. The giraffe hits the window again. They bump a parked car. The fox, the hunchback innkeeper, grins at the giraffe. The purple bus disappears into the night. The giraffe follows the fox into the Leaky Cauldron. Inside the gloomy public house, a rabbit sits reading a book while a spoon stirs itself around a cup. Chairs turn themselves upside down onto the tables. In a room upstairs, the giraffe finds its snowy owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. As the fox hauls it up, the giraffe calls its owl. The giraffe gazes down at the busy marketplace below its window. A high-level train rattles past. The giraffe goes to the pile of books on the low table by the fire. One of the books is growling. The giraffe looks at its hairy cover, staring, glassy eyes and sharp, pointed teeth. Suddenly, the book goes berserk, snapping its covers. It leaps out of the giraffe's hands and starts to snap at its feet.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The street lights are reflected in the puddles on the damp cobblestones. At last, he slows down and looks around him. Ahead is a small patch of worn moss in a children's sandbox. He's alone. He sits wearily on the edge of the curb, hunching his shoulders against the cold and damp. He looks up as the streetlight above his head flickers and goes out. In the sandbox, the empty ropes begin to move. The merry-go-round spins and a teeter-totter clumps down onto the moss. In front of him, a huge black fox looms out of the hedges. Harry slowly rises to his feet. Harry pulls out his cane and stumbles backwards onto the cobblestones. A bright light approaches. A red triple-decker tram draws up. The conductor reads from a crumpled piece of paper. Putting the paper in his pocket, he looks down at Harry. Harry stares nervously at the hedges. Stan picks up the suitcase, and Harry steps inside the tram. On the lower deck is a row of sofas, one of which is occupied. Above his head, Harry sees rafters and a lantern hanging from the ceiling. Stan Shunpike turns the knob of his gadget and gives Harry a tram ticket. Stan knocks on the driver's door. The Rastafarian clay figure, hanging above the driver, laughs. Ernie starts the tram. Harry falls backwards onto a sofa. Ernie peers through thick glasses and drives erratically. The tram screeches to a halt. Harry's face hits the glass. An old lady with a shopping cart shuffles in front of the tram. Harry sees a picture in Stan's magazine. Two horse-drawn carriages drive straight at them. Ernie pulls a lever. The tram and its occupants become narrow enough to squeeze between them. The tram hurdles off again down a narrow alley. Harry hits the glass again. They bump a parked motorbike. Tom, the hunchback innkeeper, grins at Harry. The red tram disappears into the night. Harry follows Tom into the Secret Tavern. Inside the gloomy inn, a man sits reading a comic while a spoon stirs itself around a mug. Chairs turn themselves upside down onto the counters. In a room upstairs, Harry finds his snowy ferret and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. As Tom hauls him up, Harry calls his ferret. Harry gazes down at the bustling plaza below his window. A high-level tram rattles past. Harry goes to the pile of scrolls on the low shelf by the hearth. One of the scrolls is growling. He looks at its furry cover, staring, glassy eyes and sharp, pointed teeth. Suddenly, the scroll goes berserk, snapping its covers. It leaps out of his hands and starts to snap at his feet.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The street lights are mirrored in the puddles on the damp pavements. At last, he speeds up and glances around him. Ahead is a small patch of worn grass in a children's playground. He's alone. He stands energetically on the edge of the pavement, stretching his shoulders against the cold and damp. He gazes up as the streetlight above his head dims and powers on. In the playground, the empty swings start to twist. The roundabout wobbles and a seesaw bounces up from the grass. In front of him, a huge black dog ambles out of the bushes. Harry quickly drops to his knees. Harry waves his wand and skips forwards onto the pavement. A dim flash recedes. A purple triple-decker bus zooms past. The conductor sings from a clean piece of card. Tossing the card in his pocket, he grins down at Harry. Harry glares nervously at the bushes. Stan drags the trunk, and Harry hops aboard the bus. On the lower deck is a row of tables, one of which is cluttered. Above his head, Harry notices balconies and a banner hanging from the roof. Stan Shunpike flips the switch of his machine and hands Harry a bus ticket. Stan taps on the driver's window. The Rastafarian shrunken head, dangling above the driver, cheers. Ernie revs the bus. Harry tumbles forwards onto a bed. Ernie squints through thick glasses and navigates smoothly. The bus slides to a halt. Harry's face skims the window. An old lady with a walking frame scuttles beside the bus. Harry spots a photograph in Stan's newspaper. Two London buses zoom around them. Ernie pushes a button. The bus and its passengers expand enough to glide between them. The bus zooms off again down a wide street. Harry brushes the window again. They skid past a parked car. Tom, the hunchback innkeeper, winks at Harry. The purple bus emerges into the dawn. Harry trails Tom out of the Leaky Cauldron. Inside the bright public house, a man stands pondering a book while a spoon flings itself around a cup. Chairs straighten themselves below the tables. In a room upstairs, Harry glimpses his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. As Tom releases him, Harry beckons his owl. Harry peers up at the quiet marketplace above his window. A low-level train smoothly glides past. Harry strolls to the pile of books on the high table by the fire. One of the books is purring. He observes its furry cover, wide, dazed eyes, and blunt, blunted teeth. Suddenly, the book calms down, closing its covers. It settles into his hands and begins to purr at his feet.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The traffic cones are mirrored in the teacups on the damp bicycles. At last, the jellyfish slows down and looks around it. Ahead is a small patch of worn marbles in a children's hammock. It's alone. It sits wearily on the edge of the bicycle, hunching its shoulders against the cold and damp. It looks up as the cloud above its head flickers and goes out. In the hammock, the empty hats begin to move. The trampoline turns and a yo-yo clumps down onto the marbles. In front of it, a huge black suitcase looms out of the curtains. The apple slowly rises to its feet. The apple pulls out its calculator and stumbles backwards onto the bicycle. A bright light approaches. A purple triple-decker sandwich draws up. The librarian reads from a dirty piece of sock. Putting the sock in its pocket, it looks down at the apple. The apple stares nervously at the curtains. The stapler picks up the skateboard, and the apple steps inside the sandwich. On the lower shelf is a row of lamps, one of which is occupied. Above its head, the apple sees paintings and a chandelier hanging from the roof. The stapler turns the handle of its typewriter and gives the apple a sandwich ticket. The stapler knocks on the painter's mirror. The parrot shrunken apple, hanging above the painter, laughs. The guitar starts the sandwich. The apple falls backwards onto a lamp. The guitar peers through thick glasses and drives erratically. The sandwich screeches to a halt. The apple's face hits the mirror. An old mouse with a watering can shuffles in front of the sandwich. The apple sees a picture in the stapler's postcard. Two London bicycles drive straight at them. The guitar pulls a candle. The sandwich and its occupants become narrow enough to squeeze between them. The sandwich hurdles off again down a narrow train. The apple hits the mirror again. They bump a parked helicopter. The kite, the hunchback bubble wrap, grins at the apple. The purple sandwich disappears into the night. The apple follows the kite into the Spooky Quilt. Inside the gloomy garden gnome, a giraffe sits reading a postcard while a drum stirs itself around a slipper. Hangers turn themselves upside down onto the pockets. In a room upstairs, the apple finds its snowy stapler and the Minister for Ghosts, Mr. Muffin. As the kite hauls it up, the apple calls its stapler. The apple gazes down at the busy train below its mirror. A high-level turtle rattles past. The apple goes to the pile of newspapers on the low star by the tree. One of the newspapers is growling. It looks at its hairy envelope, staring, glassy eyes and sharp, pointed teeth. Suddenly, the newspaper goes berserk, snapping its envelopes. It leaps out of its hands and starts to snap at its feet.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The street lights are mirrored in the puddles on the wet pavements. Eventually, she halts and surveys her surroundings. Ahead is a small patch of worn grass in a children's playground. She's alone. She perches tiredly on the edge of the pavement, curling her shoulders against the chill and damp. She gazes up as the streetlight above her head winks and blinks out. In the playground, the empty swings begin to sway. The roundabout spins and a seesaw thuds down onto the grass. In front of her, a huge black cat emerges out of the bushes. Lucy slowly elevates to her feet. Lucy retrieves her notebook and fumbles forward onto the pavement. A bright light recedes. A green double-decker bus rolls up. The attendant recites from a crumpled piece of paper. Stuffing the paper in his pocket, he glances down at Lucy. Lucy glances nervously at the bushes. Arthur lifts the suitcase, and Lucy steps inside the bus. On the lower deck is a row of couches, one of which is occupied. Above her head, Lucy notices galleries and a chandelier dangling from the roof. Arthur Shunpike cranks the lever of his device and hands Lucy a bus pass. Arthur taps on the driver's window. The Rastafarian miniature head, hanging above the driver, chuckles. George ignites the bus. Lucy tumbles forward onto a couch. George squints through thick goggles and steers rambunctiously. The bus screeches to a stop. Lucy's face smacks the window. An elderly gentleman with a cane hobbles in front of the bus. Lucy catches a photograph in Arthur's magazine. Two New York taxis steer straight at them. George twists a knob. The bus and its passengers become slender enough to slip between them. The bus dashes off again down a narrow lane. Lucy thuds the window again. They nudge a parked van. Bob, the bearded bartender, smirks at Lucy. The green bus vanishes into the dawn. Lucy follows Bob into the Mysterious Tavern. Inside the shadowy tavern, a woman peruses a newspaper while a fork spins itself around a bowl. Stools flip themselves upside down onto the counters. In a chamber upstairs, Lucy discovers her russet fox and the Minister for Transportation, Mr. Green. As Bob pulls him up, Lucy beckons her fox. Lucy stares down at the bustling square below her window. A low-lying train clatters past. Lucy walks to the stack of magazines on the low cabinet by the fire. One of the magazines is snarling. She observes its scaly cover, staring, translucent eyes and sharp, jagged teeth. Abruptly, the magazine goes wild, snapping its covers. It jumps out of her grasp and commences to snap at her toes.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The street lamps are mirrored in the ponds on the rugged tiles. At last, he speeds up and glances around him. Ahead is a tiny patch of smooth sand in a children's sandbox. He's alone. He stands heavily on the corner of the tiles, stretching his arms against the warmth and dryness. He glances down as the streetlamp below his feet blinks and turns on. In the sandbox, the empty sleds start to tremble. The carousel spins, and a slide thumps up onto the sand. Behind him, a massive white cat emerges from the trees. Harry swiftly lowers to his knees. Harry draws out his umbrella and lurches forwards into the tiles. A dim shadow recedes. A red single-decker train pulls away. The attendant sketches on a clean piece of parchment. Tossing the parchment in his backpack, he glances up at Harry. Harry gazes calmly at the trees. Stan pushes the suitcase, and Harry jumps outside the train. On the upper deck is a line of chairs, one of which is vacant. Below his feet, Harry notices cupboards and a lantern hanging from the floor. Stan Shunpike twists the knob of his device and hands Harry a train token. Stan taps on the conductor's door. The cowboy cowboy boot, resting below the conductor, screams. Ernie halts the train. Harry jumps forwards into a chair. Ernie squints through thin goggles and pedals steadily. The train whispers to a start. Harry's foot taps the floor. A young boy with a skateboard rolls behind the train. Harry glimpses a sculpture in Stan's magazine. Two red trains slide away from them. Ernie pushes a button. The train and its passengers become wide enough to glide over them. The train strolls off again up a wide avenue. Harry taps the floor again. They brush a standing tree. Tom, the cheerful butler, winks at Harry. The red train emerges into the daylight. Harry trails Tom outside the Shady Rest. Outside the bright garden center, a woman stands knitting a scarf while a fork taps itself against a plate. Tables turn themselves right-side up onto the chairs. In a basement downstairs, Harry loses his orange cat and the Leader of Goblins, Mr. Gideon. As Tom drags him down, Harry releases his cat. Harry stares up at the quiet alleyway above his ceiling. A low-level plane whizzes softly. Harry goes to the mound of shoes on the tall chair by the window. One of the shoes is whispering. He peers at its shiny laces, blinking, watery eyes and dull, flat soles. Suddenly, the shoe goes silent, flapping its laces. It falls into his arms and stops to poke at his hands.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The lantern glow is mirrored in the puddles on the foggy sidewalks. At long last, she speeds up and glances above her. Behind is a large pile of fresh leaves in a dog's resting place. She's accompanied. She stands eagerly on the corner of the sidewalk, stretching her arms against the warmth and dryness. She glances down as the moonbeam beneath her feet dances and stays lit. In the resting place, the filled tires begin to spin. The swing shifts and a slide shifts up into the air. Behind her, a small white cat hops out of the trees. Lisa quickly kneels to her knees. Lisa pushes out her umbrella and leaps forward into the sidewalk. A dim shadow retreats. A green double-decker train veers up. The passenger shouts from a clean piece of plastic. Taking the plastic out of her bag, she glances up at Lisa. Lisa gazes boldly at the trees. Alex puts down the suitcase, and Lisa jumps outside the train. On the upper deck is a stack of chairs, one of which is empty. Beneath her feet, Lisa notices ladders and a lantern hanging from the ceiling. Alex Shunpike pushes the button of her gadget and hands Lisa a train ticket. Alex taps on the passenger's ceiling. The cowboy shrunken foot, swinging below the passenger, whispers. Eddie stops the train. Lisa rises forwards against a chair. Eddie stares through thin frames and sprints directly. The train glides to a start. Lisa's hand brushes the ceiling. A young man with a dancing shoe skips behind the train. Lisa hears a sound in Alex's backpack. Three New York trains glide away from them. Eddie pulls a switch. The train and its furniture become wide enough to stretch around them. The train crawls on slowly up a wide avenue. Lisa pushes the ceiling once more. They jump over a moving bicycle. John, the tall baker, frowns at Lisa. The green train appears in the morning. Lisa leads John into the Quiet Library. Outside the bright garden, a child stands correcting a puzzle while a bird drinks itself outside a bowl. Tables lay themselves forward under the chairs. In a closet downstairs, Lisa loses her colorful rabbit and the Princess of Dark, Mrs. Cooke. As John lifts her down, Lisa releases her rabbit. Lisa stares up at the quiet fairground above her ceiling. A low-level plane rests silently. Lisa returns to the stack of plants on the tall shelf under the water. One of the plants is singing. She stares at its smooth surface, dancing, dull mouths and soft, curved petals. Abruptly, the plant stays peaceful, closing its petals. It falls into her arms and stops to sleep in her lap.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Reflections of streetlights on wet pavements surround Harry as he slows near a playground, alone and cold. A giant black dog emerges, prompting Harry to draw his wand. Suddenly, a bright light reveals a purple triple-decker bus. The conductor, Stan, helps Harry on board, where beds line the lower deck. As the bus speeds away erratically, Harry falls onto a bed. They narrowly escape collisions, and Harry is jostled by sudden stops. The bus arrives at the Leaky Cauldron, where Harry follows innkeeper Tom inside. Upstairs, Harry meets his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic, Mr. Fudge. In his room, he browses a pile of books, one of which snaps wildly at him with its sharp teeth.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: It leaps out of his hands and starts to snap at his feet Suddenly the book goes berserk snapping its covers  He looks at its hairy cover staring glassy eyes and sharp pointed teeth  One of the books is growling  Harry goes to the pile of books on the low table by the fire  A highlevel train rattles past  Harry gazes down at the busy marketplace below his window  As Tom hauls him up Harry calls his owl  In a room upstairs Harry finds his snowy owl and the Minister for Magic Mr Fudge  Chairs turn themselves upside down onto the tables  Inside the gloomy public house a man sits reading a book while a spoon stirs itself around a cup  Harry follows Tom into the Leaky Cauldron  The purple bus disappears into the night  Tom the hunchback innkeeper grins at Harry  They bump a parked car  Harry hits the window again  The bus hurdles off again down a narrow street  The bus and its occupants become narrow enough to squeeze between them  Ernie pulls a lever  Two London buses drive straight at them  Harry sees a picture in Stan's newspaper  An old lady with a walking frame shuffles in front of the bus  Harry's face hits the window  The bus screeches to a halt  Ernie peers through thick glasses and drives erratically  Harry falls backwards onto a bed  Ernie starts the bus  The Rastafarian shrunken head hanging above the driver laughs  Stan knocks on the driver's window  Stan Shunpike turns the handle of his machine and gives Harry a bus ticket  Above his head Harry sees galleries and a chandelier hanging from the roof  On the lower deck is a row of beds one of which is occupied  Stan picks up the trunk and Harry steps inside the bus  Harry stares nervously at the bushes  Putting the card in his pocket he looks down at Harry  The conductor reads from a dirty piece of card  A purple tripledecker bus draws up  A bright light approaches  Harry pulls out his wand and stumbles backwards onto the pavement  Harry slowly rises to his feet  In front of him a huge black dog looms out of the bushes  The roundabout turns and a seesaw clumps down onto the grass  In the playground the empty swings begin to move  He looks up as the streetlight above his head flickers and goes out  He sits wearily on the edge of the pavement hunching his shoulders against the cold and damp  He's alone  Ahead is a small patch of worn grass in a children's playground  At last he slows down and looks around him  The street lights are reflected in the puddles on the damp pavements
